trial_identification.studytitle: Tonsil and adenoid obstruction and muscle activity in nasal and oral breathing children
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Tonsil and adenoid obstruction and orbicular oris muscle activity in nasal and oral (vicious and obstructive) breathing children

interventions.interventions: Surface Electromyography (EMG) exam of facial muscles (upper and lower mouth orbicular muscles) during rest, suction and swallowing functions and isommetry . The duration of the EMG was about an hour. Each signal was recorded during 10 seconds. The overall duration of this observational study was 8 months.
interventions.comparator: The data were compared between the control group (nasal breathing children) and study group (mouth breathing children)

primaryOutcome.outcome: Correlation between the obstruction tonsil and adenoid and the upper and lower mouth orbicular muscles activity as assessed by EMG.
primaryOutcome.timepoint: The evaluation of the children was performed during three months and the outocomes was obtained after this period.

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: children with nasal or mouth (vicious or obstructive) breathing diagnosed by otorhinolaryngologist
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: children with signals and symptoms of neurological disease or syndrome, previus facial surgery or malformation, to be in speech therapy or orthodontics treatment.

ethicsAndSummary.summary: The purpose of the study was to verify the repercussion of the tonsil and adenoid obstruction on the oral muscles function, which act in the lip sealing. The function of these muscles also influences the respiratory mode (nasal or mouth breathing).
